Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Suicide Survival Narratives: How Social Statuses Affect Survivors' Cultural Narratives about Suicide Experiences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
While a great deal of research has documented sociodemographic trends in suicide risk, a more fundamental question about how people experience suicide and how they frame those experiences across their identities remains unanswered. This project will examine how suicide survivors construct cultural narratives to make meaning of their suicide experiences in order to inform suicide prevention strategies, clinical approaches to working with suicidal populations, and post-suicide social supports. We know that variation in social statuses, such as social class, gender and race, are related to increases in suicide risk. This project will analyze such variations in survivors’ cultural narratives. The identification of social mechanisms underlying suicidality will help policy makers: 1) create and refine suicide prevention by understanding the unique circumstances that precede survivors’ suicide experiences; 2) design policy to help those who have suicidal experiences transition back to life and society by identifying their unique circumstances and needs following suicide experiences; and 3) refine clinicians’ approaches to suicidal populations by explaining variation within the suicidal population across social identities. If, as evidence suggests, suicide survivors’ experiences and cultural narratives vary across social positions then these findings will have the potential to contribute to tailored suicide prevention policy and post-suicide programming, which could both save lives from suicide and improve survivors’ quality of life post-suicide experience.

Understanding how people experience surviving suicide is critical to enhance suicide prevention efforts as well as to proving support to suicide survivors. Using in-depth, semi-structured interviews with 120 suicide survivors, this project will examine how individuals’ social identities—and the salience of those identities—affect how they make sense of their suicide experiences and how these framings relate to their transitions back to life after periods of suicidal ideation or suicide attempt(s). Interview data will be analyzed using a grounded theory approach with Max QDA, a software program that allows for sorting, coding, and organizing narrative interview data. Given the paucity of qualitative work on suicide, this project is both methodologically and theoretically novel. The qualitative approach will advance contemporary sociological theory about suicide and provide information about the social mechanisms through which social categories relate to suicide experiences. More broadly the project contributes to sociological theories related to health disparities that vary by social status.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The United States is facing a suicide crisis: over the last 20 years, suicide rates have grown for most demographic groups. In response, scholars and the public ask: why? Drawing on 102 in-depth interviews with suicide survivors—those who have seriously considered and those who have attempted suicide—this project explains how social conditions promote suicide, addresses inequalities in suicide experiences, and analyzes the social policies that could mitigate rising suicide rates. By examining suicide survivors’ experiences, this research explores how we—whether mental health professionals or family and friends—can care for those facing suicidal thoughts and promote healing after a suicide attempt.

 

Intellectual Outcomes and Broader Impacts

The dissertation resulting from this project (which will be defended in AY2024-25) argues that suicide is an intimately social—not purely psychological—process. Using suicide survivors accounts of their suicidality, Co-PI Billings finds that survivors’ experiences of suicide are broader than clinical and research definitions of suicidality, which includes suicidal ideation, suicide attempts, and suicide death. Rather than focusing on suicidal intent, survivors recount experiences of desiring to die and risk-taking that could result in death, without explicit intentions to die. In this way, current definitions of suicidality that rely on suicidal intent do not capture the range of people who may need mental health resources. Broadening the definition of suicide to fit survivors’ experiences will not only reduce the stigma of suicidality by decentering intention, but also increase the number of people identified as experiencing suicidality, thereby identifying more people at risk of fatal self-harm for mental health resources.

 

In addition to a survivor-centered definition of suicidality, this work finds that gender meaningfully shapes suicide experience. While women and nonbinary people discuss emotions of self-hatred as characteristic of their suicide experiences, men discuss blame, anger, and desires to commit violence against others. Some men even shared the impulse to harm or kill others, and others described emotionally, physically, and sexually harming others as part of their suicidality. This finding highlights suicide as a fruitful location for studying masculinity-related violence. Examining men’s accounts of violence within suicide experience will provide critical implications for addressing other social ills like domestic violence, mass shootings, gendered violence more generally. 

 

This project provides lessons about how survivors access healing after attempting suicide. Overwhelmingly, survivors note that talking about suicide—especially beyond clinical settings—is a key to suicide prevention. Additionally, survivors note the elements of mental health care settings that stigmatized them and decreased their likelihood of seeking future mental health support. Mainly, mental health providers implicitly and explicitly communicating that survivors must not talk about suicide in therapy harmed survivors. The few instances where survivors found healing in mental health care settings all included the same three elements. Providers 1) communicated an openness to talking about suicidality, 2) clearly communicated mandated reporting procedures and how they worked, and 3) allowed survivors to share their in-depth thoughts about suicide without demonstrating fear. These findings have weighty implications for mental health care and suicide prevention—mental health providers should incorporate these elements into their practice to better care for suicidal patients. 

 

Lastly, the findings from this project suggest that suicide crisis responses from both the criminal justice and health care institutions require major reform. First, survivors of color face institutionalized racism that overwhelmed their evaluations of institutional experiences following a suicide attempt. Even survivors who posed no threat to themselves or others were treated primarily as criminals rather than patients by both police and health care providers in the aftermath of a suicide attempt. Survivors were handcuffed, verbally abused, and even stripped naked following suicide attempts, and survivors of color faced the most violence at the hands of the criminal justice institution. These findings suggest that first, the criminal justice system is not trained nor effective at responding to mental health crises. Second, it points to the dehumanizing elements of health care institutions in responding to suicide attempts. These violent criminal justice and healthcare experiences not only further traumatize survivors, but these data also demonstrate that they decreased survivors’ willingness to seek help, talk about suicide, and in turn, access healing. 

 

Practical Outcomes

This project will result in Co-PI Billings’ PhD in Sociology being conferred at the University of Massachusetts Amherst in AY2024-25. Billings has written three empirical papers—two of which are under peer review at scientific journals. Additionally, she has presented findings from the project at the annual meetings of the American Sociological Society, the Eastern Sociological Society, the American Association for Suicidology, and the Law & Society Association. In addition, Co-PI Billings is writing a book manuscript on the findings from this project to publish with an academic press.
